> That is definitely my biggest complaint: team play. I think some
> characters need to be more team-oriented than others.  Clerics should
> be particularly looking to help their team mates.  Also, pushing a
> cleric around just to keep yourself healed doesn't work too well 100%
> of the time.  I am just about convinced clerics need a radar to
> determine their team mates health.  So far, my legit team up to this
> point is level 8 cleric, level 7 cleric, and 2 level 3 mages.  One of
> my clerics went from level 4 to level 6 during a scenario after bring
> back lots of skeletons.
>
> Here's my take on small teams and composition:
> 1 character - mage or archmage
> 2 characters - 1 cleric and 1 mage or archmage
> 3 characters - 2 clerics and 1 mage or archmage
>
> once you get a level 7 cleric, you don't elves anymore.  I can't wait
> to get my registration completed and receive the password.
>
> My biggest problem is to create a team (without cheating) that can
> handle any scenario thrown at it, pick up all available gold/silver,
> and be strong enough to handle any large opposition.  To that end, my
> most versatile team would be 2 or 3 clerics, 2 or 3 druids, 2 or 3
> elves, and 2 mages.  every member has purpose: clerics - keep
> everybody's health up and bring in 'recruits'; mages - get to areas
> quickly; druids - creates a barrior of trees to block all attacks and
> summons fairies; and elves - walk through forest to take on foes or
> acquire gold/silver that no one else can reach.
>
> I am looking for a balance between small teams and large teams.  Once
> you get a cleric to level 4, all you have to do is surive until the
> cleric can create re-enforcements.
>
> Once I get the registration information back, I will want to create
> my
> own levels designed to test a team's versatility.
>
> About the RP, I was thinking about a fan-fic.  What I wouldn't mind
> if
> the game started off with at least 200-250 scenarios.
